title: 105_hr604
content: The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 may be cited as the "Copyright Term Extension Act" and it specifies the duration of copyright provisions. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997, also known as the "Copyright Term Extension Act," amends Section 301(c) of title 17, United States Code, changing the date to February 15, 2067. It also extends the duration of copyright for works created on or after January 1, 1978, increasing the term from fifty to seventy years. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 further amends copyright laws by extending the duration of copyright for works created but not published before January 1, 1978, from December 31, 2027, to December 31, 2047. It also increases the duration of subsisting copyrights under Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, from 47 to 67 years. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 extends copyright duration for works created before 1978 to December 31, 2047. It increases the duration of copyrights from 47 to 67 years. Amendments include changing "47" to "67" in various paragraphs and subparagraphs. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 extends copyright duration for works created before 1978 to December 31, 2047. It increases the duration of copyrights from 47 to 67 years, with amendments made to Section 102 of the Copyright Renewal Act of 1992. The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 extends copyright duration for works created before 1978 to December 31, 2047, increasing the duration from 47 to 67 years. Amendments were made to Section 102 of the Copyright Renewal Act of 1992. SEC. 3. REPRODUCTION BY LIBRARIES AND ARCHIVES. Section 108 of title 17, United States Code, allows libraries and archives to reproduce, distribute, display, or perform copyrighted works for preservation, scholarship, or research purposes during the last 20 years of the copyright term. This is permitted as long as certain conditions are met, and if the work is not subject to normal commercial exploitation. The exemption under Section 108 of title 17, United States Code, allows libraries and archives to reproduce, distribute, display, or perform copyrighted works for preservation, scholarship, or research purposes if the work is not subject to normal commercial exploitation, can be obtained at a reasonable price, or the copyright owner provides notice. This exemption does not apply to subsequent uses by users other than the library or archives. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will be effective upon enactment.
